caption: Table 2: Quantitative comparison between the existing SSC methods with our TALOS on SemanticKITTI [15] test set. We use an online benchmark server for evaluation.
description: This table presents a quantitative comparison of different Semantic Scene Completion (SSC) methods on the SemanticKITTI test set.  It shows the performance of several existing SSC methods and the proposed TALOS method, measuring their performance in terms of mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) and completion IoU (cIoU).  The results are broken down by individual semantic classes for a more detailed analysis.

caption: Table 3: Comparisons between the proposed TALOS and the existing TTA methods [25, 28]. We use SCPNet baseline and conduct evaluation on SemanticKITTI val set.
description: This table compares the performance of the proposed TALOS method against two existing Test-Time Adaptation (TTA) methods, TENT and CoTTA, and a baseline method (SCPNet) on the SemanticKITTI validation set.  The comparison is done using two metrics: mIoU (mean Intersection over Union) and cIoU (completion Intersection over Union).  The results demonstrate the effectiveness of TALOS in improving the performance compared to other methods.
section: 4.4 Comparisons with the existing TTA methods

caption: Table 4: Results of the cross-dataset evaluation, pre-training on SemanticKITTI [15], and evaluating on SemanticPOSS [39]. We compare the performance of TALOS with the baseline (SCPNet).
description: This table presents the results of a cross-dataset evaluation experiment.  A model pre-trained on the SemanticKITTI dataset is used to evaluate performance on the SemanticPOSS dataset. The goal is to assess the model's ability to generalize across different datasets and show the improvement using the TALOS method.  The table lists the mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) and the completion Intersection over Union (cIoU) for both the baseline model (SCPNet) and the TALOS-enhanced model. Class-wise results (mIoU) are also provided for different classes present in the SemanticPOSS dataset.
section: 4.5 Experiments under the severe domain gap

caption: Table 5: Results of the playback experiment.
description: This table presents the results of a playback experiment designed to evaluate the effectiveness of the gradual model adaptation in TALOS.  The experiment involved running TALOS on a SemanticKITTI validation sequence, saving the gradual model weights at a certain point, and then re-running TALOS on the same sequence using the saved weights. The table shows that the playback performance (Ours-Playback) is better than both the baseline and the first run of TALOS (Ours), indicating that the gradual model adapts to the scene over time.  The improvement suggests that TALOS effectively learns a representation of the scene through gradual model updates, rather than relying on a single pass through the data.

caption: Table 6: Impact of the number of iterations.
description: This table shows the impact of the number of iterations for updating FM on the performance of TALOS.  The results show that even with a single iteration, TALOS achieves significant gains in both mIoU and cIoU. Performance improves as the number of iterations increases, but saturation is observed after five iterations per sample.  This indicates TALOS efficiently extracts the targeted information using only a few iterations.

caption: Table A.1: Class mapping from semanticKITTI [15] to semanticPOSS [39]
description: This table shows the mapping between the class labels used in the SemanticKITTI dataset and the corresponding labels in the SemanticPOSS dataset.  This is necessary because the two datasets use slightly different class definitions, and this mapping allows for a fair comparison of results across both datasets. The mapping is used in the cross-dataset experiments discussed in the paper.

caption: Table B.2: Quantitative results on SemanticKITTI validation set.
description: This table presents a quantitative comparison of the performance of SCPNet (baseline) and TALOS on the SemanticKITTI validation set.  The metrics reported include overall mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) and class-wise Intersection over Union (cIoU), along with per-class IoU for various semantic categories like car, bicycle, person, road, and building.  It showcases the improvement achieved by TALOS over the baseline, demonstrating its effectiveness in semantic scene completion.
section: B Class-wise Results on SemanticKITTI Validation Set

caption: Table C.3: Comparisons between the proposed TALOS and TENT [25] using various SSC models.
description: This table presents ablation study results comparing the performance of TALOS against the baseline and TENT [25] across different SSC models (SSCNet [1], SSA-SC [6], and SCPNet [3]) and datasets (KITTI-360 and SemanticKITTI).  It demonstrates the consistent improvement in mIoU achieved by TALOS across various architectures and datasets, highlighting its generalizability and effectiveness as a test-time adaptation method for semantic scene completion.
section: C Result on various baseline models

caption: Table 1: The results of ablation studies for the proposed TALOS framework, conducted on SemanticKITTI val set. COMP and SEM denote the use of loss function defined in Equ. (4) and Equ. (7), respectively. Meanwhile, MOMENT and GRADUAL represent the use of FM and FG for the optimization scheme in Sec. 3.4, respectively. All metrics are in %. Best results are in bold.
description: This table presents the ablation study results of the TALOS method on the SemanticKITTI validation set.  It shows the impact of different components of the method on the performance (mIoU and cIoU). The components tested are the loss functions (COMP and SEM), the optimization scheme (MOMENT and GRADUAL), and combinations thereof. The results demonstrate the individual and combined contributions of each component to the overall performance improvement.

caption: Table D.8: Time and performance for proposed TALoS and existing TTA methods [25, 28].
description: This table compares the time per step and performance (mIoU) for the proposed TALOS method and two existing Test-Time Adaptation (TTA) methods, TENT and CoTTA, along with the baseline method.  It demonstrates the computational overhead incurred by each method in relation to its improvement in mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) for semantic scene completion.  TALOS shows a significant performance gain compared to the baseline and other TTA methods, with a moderate increase in computational time.

caption: Table D.7: Comparison with naive temporal fusion-based approaches.
description: This table compares the performance of the proposed TALOS method against two naive temporal fusion approaches (early and late fusion) and the experiment C (using only FM) in the paper. It shows the mIoU and cIoU scores for each method on the SemanticKITTI dataset.  The results demonstrate that TALOS significantly outperforms these simpler temporal fusion methods, highlighting the effectiveness of its dual optimization scheme.
